document_title: Congenital pectus excavatum in children: Causes, symptoms, diagnosis
subsection_name: lom-nguc-bam-sinh.json_2_Symptoms of sternum depression are common
subsection_content:
For most children with pectus excavatum, the only telltale sign is a slight indentation in the chest. The depth of the dent worsens as the child enters adolescence and continues to worsen into adulthood. (2)
In severe cases, the sternum can compress the lungs and heart, causing the patient to experience:
Heart beats fast; Recurrent respiratory infections; Wheezing or coughing; Chest tightness; Heart murmur; Tired; Dizzy; Shortness of breath, signs of exhaustion when exercising
Children who are often short of breath and unable to exercise much are symptoms that may occur in children with sunken chest
